Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE/LOBBY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh slides his I.D. card in the card scanner. Donna comes up behind as they walk to JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.'s looking for you.
Huh?
C.J.'s looking for you.
Donna?
Yes?
"Good morning, Josh" is a pretty good way to start the day.
Good morning.
What's up?
C.J.'s looking for you.
Tell her I'm in the office.
Josh, I'm saying C.J. is looking for you. They stop walking.
What did I do?
How would I know?
'Cause you know everything.
I do know everything.
Donna...
I'm saying you say that now, but every time I want to make a substantive contribution...
You make plenty of substantive contributions.
Like what?
This! This could be a substantive contribution.
I need a raise.
So do I! [They start walking again]
You're my boss.
Do-- but I'm not the one who pays you.
Yeah, but you could recommend that I get a raise.
Donna, she's looking for me. Do you really think this is the best time to talk about a raise?
Hmmm... I think this is the best time to talk about a raise. [smiles]
Donna, you're not a very nice person.
You got to get to know me.
Donna?
[sighs] The best I can cobble together from the small shards of information I've been able to overhear in the restroom and the Danish cart...
Donna...
Is it possible that there's a situation involving Sam, a woman, and C.J. being denied information about something? He now realizes why C.J. was looking for him.
Ok. Here's what I'm gonna do.
Hide in your office?
No. I'm not gonna hide in my office. I'm gonna go into my office and devise a strategy. That is what I do. I'm a professional. I'm not a little boy.
Hmm. That's the spirit.
But if she calls, I'm at the dentist. I'll be back in an hour.
Got it. Josh then walks into HIS OFFICE. He immediately sees C.J. sitting on his desk reading a newspaper. He SCREAMS. C.J. looks pissed.
Wow, are you stupid!

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. takes her legs off Josh's desk and folds the newspaper she was reading.

Dialogues.Line: You can't be mad at me about this, C.J.
Really? Let's see if I can, let's see if I can find it in me. Donna enters.
Wait, she was here?
Could you excuse us Donna?
How did I miss that?
I don't know, but you can kiss that raise goodbye.
Senior staff in five minutes.
Thanks. Donna leaves. Josh slams the door behind her.
A call girl?
Here's the thing...
A call girl, Josh?
You're not asking me if I'd like a call girl right now are you?
Do you have any idea how serious this is?
See, the thing is, I really don't think it is that serious.
Really?

A couple of things for you to bear in mind: he didn't know she was a call girl when he went home with her. He didn't pay her money. He didn't have knowledge of; witness or participate in anything illegal. Or for that matter, unethical, immoral or suspect.
A couple of things for you to bear in mind: none of that matters on Hard Copy!
You're overreacting.
Am I? C.J. starts moving towards Josh.
Yes.
As women are prone to do?
That's not what I mean.
That's always what you mean. [They are now face to face.]
I really think I'm the best judge of what I mean, you paranoid Berkeley shiksta feminista! [beat] Whoa. That was way too far.
No, no. Well, I've got a staff meeting to go to and so do you, you elitist, Harvard fascist missed-the-Dean's-list-two-semesters-in-a-row Yankee jackass!
Feel better getting that off your chest there, C.J.?
I'm a whole new woman. C.J. opens the door and they exit to the HALLWAY.
You look like a million bucks by the way.
Don't try to make up with me.
I'll talk to Sam.
I'll talk to Sam. They walk through the doors into the NORTHWEST LOBBY. Toby enters the building. Josh stops to talk to him. They all walk.
Toby.
Hey.
How was last night?

The longest dinner of my life. The President was up from the table every five minutes teeing off on Cashman and Berryhill. He's barking at the Secretary of State, he's scaring the hell out of Fitzwallace, which I didn't think was possible. He's snapping at the First Lady. He's talking about blowing up half of North Africa.
He's snapping at Mrs. Bartlet?
C.J. this might be a good time to tell the President about Sam and the call girl.
She knows?
Yes, I'm afraid I have that information now, and I'll be in to see you very shortly my friend.
How the hell did I get into trouble?
Today, all you had to do was get out of bed.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE PORTICO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Leo are walking outside towards the Oval Office.

Dialogues.Line: This is crap. It's been three days. This is amateur hour.
Cashman and Berryhill have to revise the response scenario so that they speak to State...
Cashman and Berryhill are dragging their feet. Cashman and Berryhill are trying to make me look like a clown. And State should concern itself with what I damn well tell 'em to be concerned with!
It doesn't work like that. [opens the door to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE]
So I've discovered.
Good morning Mr. President.
Good morning.

Moreover you know that's not the way it works. The Chiefs are working as swiftly as they can... [They enter the OVAL OFFICE. Mrs. Landingham is already there.] ...even though, frankly, time isn't a factor.
Good morning Mr. President. [hands Bartlet a paper]
Good morning.
And not to pile on, but Cashmen and Berryhill have a point with respect to the Security Council.
[standing behind his desk] Uh, Mrs. Landingham, I can't seem to find my glasses anywhere. Can you please do whatever it is you do when I can't find my glasses?
Certainly sir. [leaves]

It's been 72 hours Leo. That's more than three days since they blew him out of the sky. And I'm tired of waiting dammit! This is candy ass! We are going to draw up a response scenario today, I'm going to give the order today, we're going to strike back today.
I wish you wouldn't say 'him', Mr. President.
What?
'Three days since they blew him out of the sky.' Of course that's fine while it's just you and me sir, but in there with Fitzwallace and the Chiefs, I hope you say 'it' or 'the airplane' not 'him'.
You think I'm taking this personally.
I think--
Why the hell shouldn't I take this personally?
I think the fact that Morris was on the plane--
Americans were on that plane.
Mr. President...
I met Morris four or five times, let's not do this like he was my son.
Yes, sir.
[yelling] Mrs. Landingham!
Mr. President, I still think we need to talk about... [Mrs. Landingham enters.]
I can't fine my glasses anywhere.
Yes sir, we're on it.
Thank you.
The director is waiting.
[tries to read his watch] Uh, yeah, let's have him. [Mrs. Landingham leaves.] What did you want to say?
Nothing.
You sure?
Yeah. I got staff.
All right, I'll see you in an hour.
Thank you sir. Bartlet holds up a file and tries to read it. Leo heads towards his office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo enters from the Oval Office. Toby, Josh, C.J., Ginger and a few staffers are in the room.

Dialogues.Line: Good morning.
Hey.
Hey Leo.
[through a mouth full of food] How's his mood?
How's his mood?
Yeah.
Don't worry about it.
Toby said he's snapping--
And I said don't worry about it. [hangs up coat and moves toward his desk] Sam enters. C.J. sits on the couch.
Hey Sam, what do you know?
It's true.
You're kidding me.
I've got the transcript from the broadcast.
What broadcast?
Listen to this.
Congressman Bertram Coles appearing on a radio program in his home district.
Right.
The fifth.
Yes.
East Chester County part of Lofton.
Who we just recommended cuts in funding for the M6 Beacon.
What'd he say?

He was on the broadcast along with several officers from Cromwell Air Force Base when he said regarding the President being weak on defense: "Folks down here are patriotic, fiercely patriotic. The President better not be planning on making any visits to this base. If he does, he may not get out alive."
He said that?
You believe it?
Sitting with military officers.
Don't take the bait.
Josh.
Don't take the bait.
You better believe I'm going to take the bait.
Toby.
There oughta be a law against it.
There is a law against it.
Why'd you get him started? Leo shrugs.
How about threatening the life of the President? He was talking to other people, how about conspiracy? Those were military officers, how about treason?!
Toby.
That was a member of our own party Leo. That was a [pounds fist on Leo's desk] Democrat who said that!
It's bad, I know.
That's it?
Well, what are you gonna do?
Have the Justice Department bring him in for questioning pending felony charges.
Toby's right. What's the good of being in power if you're not gonna haul your enemies in for questioning? Sam laughs, C.J. kicks Josh in the butt.
We're really not gonna do anything about this?
Yeah Toby, because what we really need to do is arrest people for being mean to the President.
There is no law. There is no decency.
He's just getting that now.
[moving on] In the event an attack order is given today we'll need a half hour on the networks. Uh, when do they need to be told?
90 minutes.
Wait till the last minute. Toby, start working on a draft for the President.
I need to know what we're hitting.
Yeah, you and me both.
Leo.
It's military Toby. You'll know when you know.
Sam, work with the coordinating State department guy.
Beech.
And whoever the spokesperson is.
Hutchinson.
Let's do this right.
Not much chance of that.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh, C.J., Sam and Toby walk through a set of doors and towards the Lobby.

Dialogues.Line: We need to be fully stocked. State Department officials. Pentagon. We'll need the Embassy Office-
We should get McMartin on board.
He's standing by.
And Adamley at the Pentagon.
We got him.
So we're all set, good. So how do we tell them what we know without telling them what we know?
Well we don't know anything so that shouldn't be hard. Oh, Samuel, could you stop by my office around lunchtime please?
Sure. NORTHWEST LOBBY. C.J. and Josh start walking towards their offices. Sam and Toby stay behind.
Think she knows?
[distracted] Yeah.
Why?
Cause she told me she knows.
Could we talk for a moment?
Yeah, my office. I'll be right back. Sam takes off for the Communications Office. Ginger walks by. Toby grabs the report she's holding.
Hold on. Stay there. [starts walking towards a group of reporters, Ginger follows.]
Toby?
Yeah?
Did you guys hear what Bertram Coles said on the radio?
Yeah.
And?
The Secret Service investigates all threats made against the President. It's White House policy not to comment on those investigations.
Are you telling me there's going to be a criminal investigation?

[beat] I really can't comment on that right now. [looks at his watch] Damn, I gotta get back to my office. Toby walks away, Mike, Bobbi and the other reporters walk off upset. Toby hands Ginger back the report. He smiles and mouths the words 'thank you'. Toby exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is sitting behind her desk. Two staffers are taking notes from her.

Dialogues.Line: I think the thing to say is that we don't think anyone here would be disappointed if no one paid attention to the process.
And this is on agriculture?
Science and technology. [Sam knocks on the door.] Hey. [beat] We're done here. The staffers get up and leave.
Hi.
Hi.
You wanted to see me. And I think I know what it's about.

Really? You sussed it out, huh? [Sam closes the door.] Let me tell you something Sam, you're a smart guy. But if you can figure it out, and I can figure it out, what makes you think that no one in my Press Room can figure it out?
There's nothing to figure out.
You can't spend time with a call girl, you're gonna get caught.
Caught doing what?
Don't get cute with me.
You are aware that I didn't know she was a call girl when I went home with her, right?
But you called her again and went back to see her.
I went back to see her, I didn't go back to solicit her.
It doesn't make a difference.
It does make a difference.
You work in the White House, you work fifty feet from the Oval Office. And you're consorting with a...

Consorting? I'm friendly with a woman, I like this woman. This woman poses no threat to the President. And it's very likely that owing to my friendship, this woman may start living her life in bound, insuring for herself a greater future and isn't that exactly what we're supposed to be doing here?
Oh.
You're there to make her see the error of her ways.
This is ridiculous. I'm there because I like her. I'm there because it's there that I'd be if this were alcohol or drugs. I'm not sleeping with her, this isn't tawdry.
I don't care what it is, I care what it looks like.
And I care what it is! And I think it's high time we all spend a little less time looking good, and a little more time...
Being good?
Yes.
Yeah, I've heard that one before. And one other thing.
Are we done?
No, Sam, when I say there's 'one other thing' that means we're not done, that there's one other thing.
I'm resenting the hell out of this conversation.
It was tough to tell from your tone of voice.
What do you want?
I beg your pardon?
What's the one other thing?
I'm your first phone call.
When?

Before, now, in the future, anytime you're into something and you don't know what. And you can't tell me that you thought there was nothing to it, because you sat down with Josh and you sat down with Toby. Anytime you're into something and you don't know what, you don't keep it from me. I'm your first phone call. I'm your first line of defense. You have to let me protect you and you have to let me protect the President.
Is that what this is about?
[stands] What this is about Sam is you're a high profile, very visible, much noticed member...
You just said three things that all mean the same thing.
You're not going to let this out of your teeth.

Can I go now C.J.? Because what I think this is about is you. Once again letting the character cops win in a forfeit because you don't have the guts or the strength or the courage to say 'we know what's right from wrong and this none of your damn business!'
[taken aback] Really?
Yes!
Strength, guts or courage?
Yes.
You just said three things that all mean the same thing. [sits]
We're done talking now. You can go. [beat]
[opens the door and starts to leave. C.J. starts typing on her laptop] About the retaliatory strike, do you think we're going to target--?
I really don't know what we're going to target Sam. The commandant of the 2nd division doesn't tend to include me in his thinking.
I'll see you later.
Count on it. Sam exits into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA. Sam walks down the hall and smashes his fist against a wall.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: The National Security team and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral PERCY FITZWALLACE, sit around a table.

Dialogues.Line: You know what I was thinking?
What's that, Admiral?
This is different coffee than we usually have. The doors open, Bartlet and Leo enter. Everyone stands.
Keep your seats. [Everyone sits back down.]
Good morning Mr. President.
What have we got?
Three retaliatory strike scenarios.
When are they operational?
At the President's command.
No prep time?
We're there.

All three scenarios are comprehensive, meet the obligations of proportional response and pose minimal threat to U.S. personal and assets. To turn our attention to scenario one, or Pericles One, to use its code name...
What is the virtue of a proportional response?
I'm sorry.
What's the virtue of a proportional response? Why's it good? [beat] They hit an airplane, so we hit a transmitter, right? That's a proportional response.
Sir, in the case of Pericles...
They hit a barracks, so we hit two transmitters?
That's roughly it, sir.
It's what we do. I mean this is what we do.
Yes sir, it's what we do, it's what we've always done.
Well, if it's what we do, if it's what we've always done, don't they know we're going to do it?
Sir, if you would turn your attention to Pericles One.
I have turned my attention to Pericles One, it's two ammo dumps, an abandoned railroad bridge and a Syrian intelligence agency.
Those are four high rated military targets, sir.
But they know we're going to do that, they know we're going to do that. Those areas have been abandoned for four days. We know that from the satellites. We have the intelligence.
Sir.
They did that, so we did this, it's the cost of doing business, it's been factored in, right?
Mr. President...
Am I right or am I missing something here?
No sir, you're right sir.
Then I ask again, what is the virtue of a proportional response?
It isn't virtuous Mr. President. It's all there is sir.
It is not all there is.
Sir, Admiral Fitzwallace...
Excuse me Leo, but pardon me Mr. President, just what else is there?

A disproportional response. Let the word ring forth from this time and this place, you kill an American, any American, we don't come back with a proportional response, we come back [bangs fist on table] with total disaster!
Are you suggesting we carpet-bomb Damascus?

General, I am suggesting that you and Admiral Fitzwallace and Secretary Hutchinson and the rest of the national security team take the next sixty minutes and put together a U.S. response scenario that doesn't make me think we are just docking somebody's damn allowance! [gets up and leaves the room. Everyone stands.]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: A nervous looking CHARLIE YOUNG stands and looks around the room. Donna and Josh are outside walking towards the room, you can hear faint echoes of banter.

Dialogues.Line: I haven't eaten lunch yet, if anyone's going to the thing.
What do you want? [They appear in the doorway and walk in.]
I would like a salad. I would like a soup of some kind and if you were to run across a sandwich, then hang the expense.
Right.
And I would like a bottle of water.
This is Charles Young. [hands him Charlie's file and leaves.]
I'm supposed to vet you.
I beg your pardon?
I'm supposed to vet you, vet you; investigate to discover... if there are problems. I'm Josh Lyman, deputy chief of staff.
How are you?
Is it Charles?
Charlie.
Charlie, you can have a seat if you like.
I don't mind standing. Donna walks down the hall.
Uh, Donna!
[appears in the doorway] What?
Never mind the salad, I'm not going to eat it anyway.
Fine.
But I would like a bottle of water as soon as humanly possible.
Fine. [leaves]

So... have a seat. [Charlie does.] I'm sure you understand why we have to go through this. It's a very sensitive job. It's also a very hard job. Twenty-hour days aren't uncommon, long trips at the last minute, a lot of wait and hurry up. Moreover there will be times when you'll have to make yourself invisible in plain sight, as well as an undeniable force in front of those who want more time than we're willing to give. Sometimes the people I'm talking about will be kings and prime ministers, you understand so far?
Uh, sir, I'm sorry but I think there's been some sort of mistake.
Really?
See, I came here, I filled out an application form...
Yeah, I have your paperwork.
Right, see, I came here, I was looking for a job as a messenger and I had an interview with Miss DiLaguardia and she told me to wait.
Yes.
And then she told me to come here.
Yes, that's because we asked Miss DiLaguardia to keep an eye out. She's recommending you for a different job.
Sir, if you don't mind me asking--
Personal aide to the President, and you don't have to call me 'Sir'.
I don't understand.
Personal aide to the President, traditionally a young guy, 20 to 25 years old, excels academically, strong in personal responsibility and discretion, presentable appearance.
Sir--
We obviously get a lot of candidates that meet those qualifications, the rest is just gut instinct. [beat] Or you could bribe me.
Uh, um, sir...
Seriously Charlie, we call the President 'Sir' everyone else is 'hey, when am I gonna get that thing I asked for?'
[enters and hands Josh a bottle of water] Water.
See, that's not... see, there's been some kind of mistake.
[reading a report] I'll say. Donna! [She stops at the door.]
I should go. [stands]
'Insuccessful'?
What's the problem?
I don't think we're allowed to make up our own words.
Oh, and like there's no chance it's a typo.
Change it, would you? Serious people are going to read that. [Donna takes the report and exits.]
Charlie, you're standing again.
Well, see, I came here for a messenger job.
Why aren't you in college?
Well, uh...
These transcripts. Your grades are better than mine.
Mr. Lyman.
Well, no, not really, but they're close.
It was an easy school.
No, come one, I'm looking at recommendations from guidance counselors, I'm looking at ACT scores. You didn't want to go to college?
Well, I have a little sister at home.
You take care of her?
Yes sir.
Your parents are gone?
My mom, she's a police officer. She was shot and killed on duty a few months ago. Five months ago.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet walks in and sits down.

Dialogues.Line: Keep your seats. There's a delegation of cardiologists having their pictures taken in the Blue Room. You wouldn't think you could find a group of people more arrogant than the fifteen of us, but there they are right upstairs in the Blue Room. You called me?

Yes, sir. Mr. President we put together a scenario by which we attack Hassan airport. Its three main terminals and two runway. In addition to the civilian causalities, which could register in the thousands, the strike would temporally cripple the region's ability to receive medical supplies and bottled water. I think Mr. Cashmen and Secretary Hutchinson would each tell you what I'm sure you already know sir. That this strike would be seen at home and abroad as a staggering overreaction by a first time Commander in Chief. That without the support of our allies, without a Western Coalition, without Great Britain and Japan and without Congress, you'll have doled out a five thousand dollar punishment for a fifty buck crime sir. Mr. President, the proportional response doesn't empty the options box for the future, the way an all out assault--
[waves him off] Thank you. [beat] Does anyone have a cigarette? An officer pulls out a pack and a lighter and slides it towards the President. Bartlet pulls out a cigarette and lights it.
This other plan...
Pericles One.
Pericles One. No civilian causalities?
We can't promise that.
But you're as certain as you can be?
Yes sir.
And what are the military implications?
We'll cripple both their intelligence network and their surface to air strike capabilities.
Very well. [pause, to Leo] How does this work?
You give me the go order sir. An officer moves over to the phone. Bartlet sighs. Pause.
Mr. President? [Bartlet nods.] This is Fitzwallace, I have a go order from the President. Start the clock on Pericles One. Stand by for confirmation code.
We're underway. Bartlet throws his cigarette in a glass of water. He gets up and is standing in the doorway.
Well done.
Fifty buck crime. [to Leo] I honestly don't know what the hell we're doing here. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Charlie and Josh are sitting at the table. Josh has a bunch of paperwork in front of him.

Dialogues.Line: Charlie, I've got some questions here for you from the Council's office, as well as the Department of the Treasury and the Office of Internal Security. These questions are all routine, there's no cause for concern. Ready?
Mr. Lyman--
'Have you ever tried to overthrow the government?'
Is it because the messenger job is not available anymore? Because maybe if I came back at a different time.

Charlie, this job's actually better than the messenger job. It pays more, you don't have to ride around town on a bicycle and instead of being a messenger, you get to be personal aide to the President.
I see. So, maybe if I come-- Sam knocks on the door and walks in.
Hey, Sam. This is Sam Seaborn, he's deputy communications director. This is Charlie Young. He's here for Ted's job.
It's nice to meet you, don't get up.
Um, I was here for the messenger job.
Debbie's got an eye for personnel.
I've got a driver's license and my own bike so...
I gotta ask you some more questions...
Have you ever tried to overthrow the government?
No sir.
What the hell's been stopping you? [Josh and Sam laugh.]
Seriously Charlie, I have to ask you about your personal life.
No, you don't.
Yes, I do.
Why?
Because I do.
Charlie, are you gonna come to work early, stay late, do your job efficiently and discretely?
As I was saying to Mr. Lyman--
Thank you. What more do you need to know?
Charlie, I wonder if you could tell me about your social life, your friends, what you like to do?
Josh, I cannot believe you.
Well, uh, there's my sister Deena and uh, I'm not sure what you're asking.
He's asking if you're gay, Charlie, and I wouldn't answer the damn question.
All right, that's it Sam, let's take a walk. [gets up]
You know what, feel free to sue our asses off. I'll represent you.
Let's go. Josh leads Sam out of the room and into the HALLWAY.
What the hell was that about?
This is ridiculous.
It's not all that ridiculous.
I know the difference between right and wrong.
It's not like you didn't know you'd be held to a high standard when you took this job.
I don't mind being held to a higher standard, I mind being held to a lower one.
I gotta say Sam, digging your heels in...
I was just talking.
I understand...
'Digging my heels in'? Another word for that would be principle?
I'm just saying! Toby walks in between them on his way to Leo's office.
Leo's office. JOSH & SAM What?
It's happening.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO's OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Margaret walks in, C.J. is already inside.

Dialogues.Line: He's right here. Sam, Josh and Toby walk in.
It's happening?
Yeah, that's what I hear.
[walks in] The order was given at 16:27, codename Pericles One. Four targets, all military. Two munitions dumps in Northern Rishan, Southian bridge and an IHQ.
What's the estimated time?

About 6:30 Eastern, you can come to the Sit Room in twenty minutes for a weapons briefing. In the meantime, Toby, Sam, the President will go on network at nine, so start zeroing in. [Toby, Sam, and C.J. start to leave.] Hey guys, no phone calls in or out. C.J., nothing to the press until you get the high sign from me. No head starts. Sam and Toby leave.
They're gonna wonder what all the fuss is about.
Then let's not have any fuss.
I could use a few minutes with the President at some point.
You and me both.
I'm not kidding Leo, this is the...
You'll be there.
This is the first...
You'll be there.
He'll talk to me?
Yes. C.J. leaves. Josh is standing at the back of the room.
How you doing?
Fine.
Leo, Toby says he's snapping at the First...
Not now Josh. I mean, you're right, but not now. [beat] Margaret!
Hey Leo, can I ask you a question?
What?

I'm interviewing this kid for Ted Miller's job, and he's a real special kid. He's applied himself in school, I'm sure he'd be articulate if he wasn't terrified. He's postponing college until his sister gets out of high school.
Where are the parents?
Father's long gone. His mother was a uniformed cop here in D.C.
Was?
She was shot and killed in the line five months ago. [beat] I really like him Leo. I want to hire him.
What's the problem?
He's black.
So's the Attorney General and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs?
They don't hold the door open for the President.
What are you worried...?
I'm not wild about the visual. A young black man holding his overnight bag?
Josh, I hold the door open for the President, it's an honor. This is serious business Josh. This isn't casting. We get the guy for the job and we take it from there.
Good.
And I'm fairly sure I'm right about this.
Yeah. Good. [beat] Two hours?
Uh, a little less.
[enters] Chairman Fitzwallace.
Send him in.
We'll be fine.
Yeah.
[enters] Oh, things have moved since I was in this office last.
How are you Admiral? [reaches to shake hands] Josh Lyman.
Josh, you don't have to introduce yourself, and I'm fine thanks.
Tough day.
It'll be a lot tougher on them than on us.
Good. [exits]
You're gonna have to set him down Leo.
I know.
He's gonna have to talk to the country a little bit. This is not the last one of these we're gonna have to do, but you're gonna have to set him down.
Any advice?
It's not my place.
Yeah, it is.
Tell him it's always like this the first time. Tell him he's doing fine.
He's not doing fine.
Yeah, he is. Presidents don't make new friends, that's why they gotta keep their old ones. You'll know what to say. [starts to leave]
Yeah. [beat] Uh, hey Fitz?
Yeah?
The President's personal aide, they're looking at a kid. Do you have any problem with a young black man waiting on the President?
I'm an old black man and I wait on the President.
The kid's gotta carry his bags...
You gonna pay him a decent wage?
Yeah.
You gonna treat him with respect in the workplace?
Yeah.
Then why the hell should I care?
That's what I thought.
I've got some real honest to God battles to fight Leo. I don't have time for the cosmetic ones.
Thanks Admiral. Good luck.
See you later. The admiral exits into the HALLWAY with an officer. Toby is walking by, his arms are full of papers and files.
Evening Toby.
Evening sir. Sorry I can't stop...
Go. [walks off] Toby walks into the ROOSEVELT ROOM. Staffers walk frantically in and out. Ginger walks in. Josh stands in front of the table.
Estimated BDA?
It's my first bombing, I don't know yet. [Ginger exits.]
Toby, you need help with anything because...
No! [exits]
Sheila, if you need me for anything... Standing here with absolutely nothing to do.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS BULLPEN - DAY
Scenes.Description: Staffers continue to wander around frantically. Toby walks in and into his office. Cathy is standing at her desk. The phone rings.

Dialogues.Line: White House Communications, I'm sorry Toby's not available to speak on the phone at the moment. No, Sam's not available either. [C.J. enters.] Why isn't anyone available to speak on the phone?
I don't know, they're planning my surprise party. C.J. stands in the doorway of TOBY's OFFICE. Toby and Sam are writing.
Unprovoked and cold-blooded.
It's needs a third.
Toby?
Quickly.
The AGM 84 Islam.
Cathy! Sam cut the paragraph ten minutes ago.
[while walking across the bullpen] It's coming out on the redline.
The 84 Islam?
Standoff land attack missile. Distinguish it from the AGM 84D or Harpoon, which is an anti-shive missile.
Thank you. [leaves]
The third thing?
Unwarranted, unprovoked...
And cold-blooded. Unwarranted.
Unprovoked.
And cold-blooded. Great.
[gets up and walks away] I just need a...
Where you going?
Two seconds. Just two seconds. [Sam walks through the office into the HALLWAY where C.J. is standing.] C.J., listen.
What?
I'm sorry about before.
Yeah.
I'm just really very fond of her is all.
Go back to work.
Right.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is walking through the lobby into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA. A gaggle of reporters is standing at the door to the PRESS ROOM.

Dialogues.Line: C.J., what's all the activity?
What activity?
Fitzwallace was in Leo's office.
[starts walking slowly towards her office] Admiral Fitzwallace is Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Leo McGarry is White House chief of staff, I'm your host C.J., let's play our game.
Is it happening?
No.
Would you know if it was?
Guys.
Why all the activity?
Menudo's in the building. I gotta go. The reporters once again walk away upset. C.J. heads towards her office. A reporter, DANNY CONCANNON, stands by her door.
Oh man. I'd honestly think that you of all people.
We need to talk.
Danny, I haven't called a full lid, they'll obviously be a briefing if the President has engaged the use of military force.
Thanks. Since I've only been a White House reporter for seven years, I appreciate you clearing that up.
[beat] What?
Not for nothing, but I know Sam Seaborn's been going around with a three thousand dollar a night call girl. And I thought you should know that I know. [beat] Ask me inside, C.J.
Inside. They walk into her office and close the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh walks down the hallway, leans on a wall near Donna's desk.

Dialogues.Line: Where's Charlie?
He's filling out his employment stuff at Personnel.
How's he doing?
He looked pretty freaked.
He's a gamer. I can pick 'em.
If you say so. Pause. Josh looks around, whistles a little bit, and generally looks bored.
I've got nothing to do.
I can see that. A staffers runs up, grabs something from near where Josh is standing and runs off.
Woo! Excuse me. Everyone's running around like the future of the world depends on it, which I suppose it does, everyone running around, working. Me, I've got nothing to do.
Yes.
I'm like a writer on a movie set.
Have you ever been on a movie set?
No, but I hear stories.
You wanna do mail?
[sitting down] I suppose there's some comfort in knowing that whatever's going to happen today has already happened.
Josh, your office sucks.
I don't understand it. Why can't you tell me when there's someone in my office?
The first time I didn't know, the second time I didn't care that much. [gets up and leaves]
I mean it, it's a hole.
[gets up and walks toward her and his office] Why are you here?
I start work next week, I came to get psyched. JOSH'S OFFICE. They both enter.
You picked a really bad time to get psyched.
Because the President gave the attack order and you're getting ready to go on the air?
No, it's because--
Please Josh, everyone's running around looking casual, Toby and Sam are locked in with the speechwriters and you've got nothing to do. What is it? An IHQ and a couple of armories?
You wanna say it a bit louder Mandy, I don't Syrian Air Defense Command heard you.
I brought you a present.
Why are you being nice to me? [sits behind his desk]
Cause I'm really psyched to get started work.
It's been pretty bad around here since it happened.
I had a hunch.
The combination of American lives and Morris, the idea of using any force at all.
We always said he'd be in his head.
He wasn't ready for it.
How do you get ready for it?
What did you bring me?
What?
I want my present.
Yeah. [grabs something out of her bag and gives it to Josh] It's a picture I found.
It's a picture of you and me and someone's drawn all over my face with magic marker.
That was me.
Ah.
During my period of hating you.
Well, that could have been pretty much any time, couldn't it?
Sure. [starts walking around Josh's desk, towards him] This was taken the night we met. At that seafood place by the Democratic Leadership Conference.
Look at that.
You couldn't stop staring at me.
Well, you were wearing quite the ensemble that night Madeline.
[sits on the edge of his desk] I don't think it was the wardrobe you were staring at there, Lucky. [Josh laughs.] You guys are doing okay, Josh. The phone rings. Josh picks it up.
Yeah... yeah. [hangs up] They found a job for me.
I'll see you next week.
Listen, you're not gonna be this nice to me when we're working together, right?
Not a chance. [leaves]
That's what I thought. [puts the picture on his desk. Donna walks in.] Hey. What's up? Donna and Josh exit.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Danny and C.J. are sitting across from each other at her desk.

Dialogues.Line: I obviously don't have enough for a story, but as a courtesy to you C.J. I just wanted to let you know I'm gonna be asking around.
Danny, it's gonna be much ado about nothing.
It doesn't look that way.
But it is that way and I just got through telling you it's that way.

Sam knows the difference between right and wrong and so do you. Would it make my life easier if he wasn't friends with this woman? Absolutely. But Sam is a grown up and I don't get to choose his friends and your readers don't get to judge them. And I'll tell you what else, there's something commendable about Sam's behavior here, don't ask me what but there is, and I'm stickin' by him until the President orders me otherwise and I'm going to look very unfavorably on those who seek only to make us look like fools.
Whoa. Down girl. I'll drop it.
Good.
I'll drop it.
Thank you.

But C.J. you better get D'ed up here. Because not everyone's a good guy and you're gonna start to get traction on something that not everyone's a fan of and they're gonna put a tail on Seaborn, if they haven't already. Remember, I found out about this somehow and I wasn't there.
I don't supposed you'd tell me...
No way. My point is, they'll keep it in their pocket until the eve of something big. Bill signing, State of the Union, maybe the convention. The phone rings. C.J. answers.
Yeah. I'll wait for him. [to Danny] Hang on, I'm gonna give you a ten minute head start on something.
What for?
For being a good guy.
What's the tip?
[into phone] Yeah, thank you. [hangs up] We're out of Syrian air space.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is giving Charlie the tour. They're walking towards the Oval Office.

Dialogues.Line: This used to be the White House Council's office 'til Toby and the Communications staff conquered and pillaged. The Map Room. Roosevelt Room. Oval Office. Chief of Staff. I guess the only thing left to do is to say hello to the President. Charlie stops walking.
We're going on the air in a few minutes with a national address so I don't know how much... where the hell'd he go? [beat] Charlie. Josh motions for Charlie to come into the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet, Toby and Sam all walk in the room towards the desk. Staffers are still walking around frantically, they are joined by a crew of cameramen, gaffers and stage managers. There are television monitors in the room and extra lights.

Dialogues.Line: What happened to paragraph nine?
In the red line sir.
I'm sorry, paragraph eight.
We cut that half an hour ago.
You have to read between the lines.
Well, I want to see it again.
You should look at the new paragraph.
I can't look at anything fellas. Mrs. Landingham! I need my glasses!
Sir, she's talking to the porters right now.
Mr. President.
When do we get the BDA?
Uh.
There's a problem with that sir.
Why!?
Ordinarily we get help from inside the Syrian Intelligence. Josh and Charlie enter.
So what's the problem?
We just blew up the Syrian Intelligence.
Oh, for crying out loud, will somebody get on the phone to CNN and find out if we hit anything!
Mr. President, it's the BDA sir. [hands Bartlet a report]
Thank you! Now if I had my glasses.
[enters with Nancy] The porters have searched your bedroom from top to bottom.
This has been since this morning, we could have brought in an optometrist by now.
An optometrist can't fold his equipment into a briefcase.
They have those machines with the lenses.
I don't need an optometrist now, thank you Nancy. I just need to glasses he prescribed.
[enters] Mr. President, if you'll take a minute or two to familiarize yourself with the phoenix.
I got the briefing on the phoenix.
You understand that I'm not talking about the sidewinder.

The phoenix. I got the briefing on the phoenix last night, I studied the report, Hutchinson was there, in my private study. Charlie whispers something to Josh, who are farther away from all the action.
The phoenix, the A61, the sparrow, and the sidewinder. Are we covered?
Yes, sir.
Very well.
Ten minutes to air Mr. President.
Tell him.
For want of a pair of glasses.
Try mine sir.
[outside] We're looking.
[also outside] She's looking.
Thank you. [tries on C.J.'s glasses]
While they're looking sir, in the meantime can you take a look at the new paragraph?
Aw, crap. I can't see anything with those.
Charlie, tell him.
Mr. President... [Everyone stops to look.] You said you read the phoenix report...
What!?
You said you read the phoenix report in your private study last night, sir.
What of it? Who is this?
[to Nancy] Have a steward go the President's study. Have him look under the papers on the coffee table. [Nancy nods and exits.]
Mr. President, this is Charles Young...
I don't have anytime for new people now!

Alright, that's it. [beat] Excuse me, Mr. President, a minute please. Charlie walks out of the room. Bartlet and Leo head towards Leo's office. Toby flashes Leo a ten-minute sign with his hands. Leo nods.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO's OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Leo walks around and closes all the doors while he's talking.

Dialogues.Line: What do you need, Leo?

Well, you've gone through everyone who works for you and everyone who's married to you. I didn't know who else you could get mad at, so I was afraid the American people might be next. Oh, by the way, when we're done here you're sending Abby some flowers.

[pause] Did you know that two thousand years ago a Roman citizen could walk across the face of the known world free of the fear of molestation? He could walk across the earth unharmed, cloaked only in the words 'Civis Romanis' I am a Roman citizen. So great was the retribution of Rome, universally understood as certain, should any harm befall even one of its citizens. Where was Morris' protection, or anyone else on that plane? Where is the retribution for the families and where is the warning to the rest of the world that Americans shall walk this earth unharmed, lest the clenched fist of the most mighty military force in the history of mankind comes crashing down on your house!? In other words, Leo, what the hell are we doing here?
We are behaving the way a superpower ought to behave.
Well our behavior has produced some pretty crappy results. In fact, I'm not a hundred percent sure it hasn't induced them.
What are you talking about?
I'm talking about two hundred and eight-six American marines in Beirut, I'm talking about Somalia, I'm talking about Nairobi.
And you think ratching up the body count's gonna act as a deterrent?
You're damn right.

Then you are just as dumb as these guys who think that capital punishment is going to be a deterrent for drug kingpins. As if drug kingpins didn't live their day to day lives under the possibility of execution. And their executions are a lot less dainty than ours and tend to take place without the bother and expense of due process. So my friend, if you want to start using American military strength as the arm of the Lord, you can do that, we're the only superpower left. You can conquer the world, like Charlemenge, but you better be prepared to kill everyone and you better start with me cause I will raise up an army against you and I will beat you!
He had a ten-day-old baby at home.
I know.
We are doing nothing. They dest...
We are not doing nothing. Four high rated military targets.
And this is good?

Of course it's not good, there is no good. It's what there is. It's how you behave if you're the most powerful nation in the world. It's proportional, it's reasonable, it's responsible, it's merciful. It's not nothing, four high rated military targets.
Which they'll rebuild again in six months.
So we'll blow 'em up again in six months! We're getting really good at it. [beat] It's what our fathers taught us.

Why didn't you say so? [beat] Oh man Leo. When I think of all the work you put in to get me to run. [both sit] When I think of all the work you did to get me elected. I could pommel your ass with a baseball bat. They laugh.
Oh, here's one you'll like. Bertram Coles--
Oh, I like anything that starts with 'Bertram Coles'. Let's have it.
Coles goes on the radio yesterday and he says people in his district love America and you better not come down there cause you might not get out alive. [laughs]
Bert's calling me out?
Apparently, the people in Bert's district are so patriotic that if the President of the United States himself were to show up, they'd kill him. They both laugh.
Ziegler must be ballistic.
Toby is on it.
Oh, by the way, who was that kid before? The one who figured out where my glasses are?
Well, if you want him, that's your new body man.
What's his story?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Outside the Oval Office, Charlie stands in the hall. Josh walks out to meet him.

Dialogues.Line: This was just, I think, a bad day. I have to tell you, he's ordinarily an extremely kind man placing a very high premium on civility. Today, it's just been a difficult few days for him.
I think I should probably go.
[appears in the doorway] Excuse me Charlie. Can I see you inside please? Come on, it's okay. Charlie, Bartlet and Josh all enter THE OVAL OFFICE.
I'm Jed Bartlet.
I'm Charles Young.

But you prefer Charlie, right? Listen, Leo McGarry filled me in on the situation with your mother, I'm so very sorry. I hope you don't mind but I took the liberty of calling Tom Connolly, the FBI Director. We had the computer spit out some quick information, you're mother was killed by a Western .38 Revolver firing K.T.W.s, or what are known as 'Cop Killer bullets', now we have not had a whole lot of success banning that weapon and those bullets off the streets, but we're planning on taking a big whack at it when Congress gets back from recess. So, what do you say, you wanna come help us out?
Yes sir, I do.
Thanks. Bartlet and Charlie shake hands.
Thirty seconds please!
All set? Bartlet is standing in front of his desk, Leo in front of it. Everyone else is behind the camera and monitors.
You tell me.
That's a pretty ugly tie.
My granddaughter gave me this tie.
So, my nephew gave me an ashtray he made at summer camp.
Get away from me. Somebody throw this guy out of the building!
Stand by. Bartlet sits. Leo moves back with the rest. Charlie and the senior staff are standing around one monitor.
I've never felt like this before.
It doesn't go away.
[on monitor] Here now, the President.

My fellow Americans, good evening. A short while ago I ordered our Armed Forces to attack and destroy four military targets in Northern Syria, this in response to the unwarranted, unprovoked... DISSOLVE TO:
...and cold-blooded downing three days ago of an unarmed Air Force jet carrying 58 passengers and the flag of the United States.
